cmd.cites.cmd.second.line.cite: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information § 6:8

prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Defences to Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: A fiduciary duty does not exist unless some or all of the characteristics of a fiduciary duty can be proven. Those characteristics are:
The fiduciary has scope for the exercise of some discretion or power.
The fiduciary can unilaterally exercise that power or discretion so as to affect the beneficiary's legal or practical interests.
The beneficiary is peculiarly vulnerable to or at the mercy of the fiduciary holding the discretion or power.[1]
If there is no fiduciary relationship between the plaintiff and the defendant, there can be no breach of fiduciary duty.

The case of Genesta Manufacturing Ltd. v. Babey[2] involved an action for damages and injunctive relief by Genesta against Babey, a former employee. Babey, who was originally the “number two man” in the company, was eventually replaced by another in terms of status, although Babey did not receive a decrease in salary. While Babey was with Genesta, he attempted to negotiate an agreement with North American Philips, but eventually submitted to the latter a proposal on behalf of his own company, Viva Lighting Panels Inc., rather than Genesta. In addition, after Viva Lighting's incorporation, Babey attempted to solicit Genesta's customers.

Genesta claimed relief on the basis that Babey had attempted to misappropriate a corporate opportunity. It relied on Canadian Aero Service Ltd. v. O'Malley,[3] in which the Supreme Court of Canada held that those who have a fiduciary duty may not breach that duty. However, it was held that, at the time Babey was dealing with North American Philips, he was an employee to whom no one reported, and his acts were subject to the approval of his “replacement” and the CEO of Genesta. Therefore, Barr J. concluded that, when dealing with North American Philips, Babey had acted as a representative of the plaintiff and was not a senior employee. As such, the defendant did not owe a fiduciary duty to the plaintiff. In support of its conclusion, the court quoted the following from Canadian Aero Service Ltd. v. O'Malley:

Strict application against directors and senior management officials is simply recognition of the degree of control which their positions give them in corporate operations [and] an acknowledgment … of the need to compel obedience by [the corporation] and by its promoters, directors and managers to norms of exemplary behavior.[4]

If a fiduciary relationship does exist, the defendant may argue that there was no breach of fiduciary duty. In Coin-A-Matic (Pacific) Ltd. v. Saibil,[5] the defendant, Saibil, was a vice-president of the plaintiff and, in the circumstances, had a fiduciary duty to Coin-A-Matic. Saibil later left his employment and joined several others in setting up a company in competition with the plaintiff. The corporate defendant utilized the lease form and comparative analysis techniques of the plaintiff in its competing business. Coin-A-Matic brought a claim for breach of “faithful performance”, unfair use and wrongful conversion of Coin-A-Matic's confidential business information.[6] The claim for breach of fiduciary duty was dismissed because:
the form of the plaintiff's lease was not confidential and had been provided to competitors in an effort to standardize the form of contract used in the industry; and
the comparative analysis techniques were well known by most salespersons.
Since neither document was considered confidential business information, the claim for protection of that information failed.[7]

In Kaptor Financial Inc. v. Alexander,[8] the defendants in an action that sought leave to commence a derivative action brought motions for orders striking the claim in its entirety on the grounds that the claim failed to disclose a reasonable cause of action. The defendants were the applicants in a receivership application which resulted in a receivership order.[9]

The central claim in the action was that each of the defendants obtained certain information regarding Insignia which the plaintiffs alleged was confidential. The specific information pertained to the termination provisions of two licence agreements between Insignia and each of Disney and Nickelodeon. The plaintiffs asserted in the action that receipt of the Confidential Information imposed an obligation on the defendants not to bring the Receivership Application.[10]

The Investor Defendants received the Confidential Information at the time of, and for use in connection with, the negotiations in the spring of 2012 between the defendants and the plaintiffs that resulted in a forbearance agreement and a side letter, each dated April 17, 2012, that were executed by each of the plaintiffs. The breach of the Forbearance Agreement triggered the right of the applicants in the Receivership Application to rely on consents executed by each plaintiff to the appointment of a receiver over its property and assets, pursuant to the terms of the Side Letter.[11]

The plaintiffs alleged that receipt of the Confidential Information imposed a fiduciary duty on the defendants which was breached when the Receivership Application was commenced on the grounds that such action was not in the best interests of Insignia.[12]

The motions judge concluded that the Investor Defendants were not subject to any statutory fiduciary obligations. They were neither officers nor directors of any of the plaintiffs. They were therefore not per se directors. Several of the elements that must be demonstrated for an ad hoc fiduciary duty to arise were missing in the Action as pleaded. First, there was no element of vulnerability in the relationship between the defendants and Insignia. The relationship was, instead, a traditional debtor-creditor relationship. Even if it could be said that the defendants exercised some discretion or power in this relationship—being the discretion or power to seek the appointment of a receiver—Insignia was not vulnerable to or at the mercy of the defendants in the sense applicable for the test in Elder Advocates of Alberta Society v. Alberta, 2011 SCC 24, [2011] 2 S.C.R. 261 (S.C.C.). Admittedly, Insignia had limited options as a result of its financial condition. However, that was not enough to satisfy the vulnerability requirement. Moreover, Insignia was represented by both Inspektor and experienced legal counsel in the negotiations. Insignia freely entered into the Forbearance Agreement and the Side Letter with independent legal advice. There was also no pleading that the defendants undertook to act in the best interests of Insignia. There was also no basis for inferring such an undertaking in the circumstances. Mere receipt of confidential information provided voluntarily by a party is not sufficient to constitute or establish such an undertaking unless the reservation of confidential treatment and a prohibition of use is expressly agreed upon at the time. By delivering the Confidential Information to the Investor Defendants in the spring of 2012, the plaintiffs authorized the use of that information by the recipients for their personal benefit in the negotiations. Unfortunately, the Investor Defendants did not agree with the plaintiffs that it was in their best interests to refrain from proceeding with a receivership application. However, there is no principle of law that says that, in their capacities as investors in the Kaptor group of companies, the Investor Defendants were required to refrain from acting in their best interests as they determined them to be even though the consequence could be the termination of the Licence Agreements.[13]

The plaintiffs appeared to acknowledge this by pleading that there was a “transmitted fiduciary duty” from the other defendants “by knowingly assisting with their breaches”. This claim could not succeed against the Investor Defendants even if such a concept of “transmitted fiduciary duty” existed. There is, however, no such concept under the law of equity. Insofar as the pleading asserted a claim of knowing assistance in a breach of the fiduciary duties of one or more of the other defendants regarding the commencement of the Receivership Application, such claim could not stand in view of the determinations that the pleadings failed to disclose a viable cause of action in respect of these defendants. Accordingly, the pleadings against the Investor Defendants were struck as failing to disclose a cause of action.[14]

The plaintiffs also alleged that John Uster and Steven Uster received the Confidential Information as fiduciaries by virtue of their positions as directors or officers of one of the Kaptor group of companies. For a period of time ending in December 2011, John Uster was a director of the plaintiff Kaptor Financial Inc. and he received the Confidential Information in that capacity. As such, during the period that he was a director, John Uster would have been subject to a duty to act in the best interests of Kaptor Financial Inc. However, John Uster resigned as a director of Kaptor Financial Inc. in December 2011 before the commencement of the negotiations that resulted in the Forbearance Agreement and the Side Letter. After his resignation, John Uster ceased to have any fiduciary duty to Kaptor Financial Inc. He stood in exactly the same position relative to the plaintiffs, and in particular relative to Insignia, as each of the other Investor Defendants, except to the extent that he was subject to any restriction on the use of confidential information received while a director. There was, however, no basis for any such restriction. There was no evidence that, while a director of Kaptor Financial Inc., he undertook that he would not support a receivership application in furtherance of his interests as a creditor as a result of receipt of the Confidential Information. More importantly, given that the Confidential Information was disclosed by the plaintiffs to the Investor Defendants for the purposes of the negotiations in the spring of 2012, there could be no claim against John Uster in respect of his alleged use of the Confidential Information. By delivering the Confidential Information to the Investor Defendants in the spring of 2012, the plaintiffs authorized the use of that information by the parties participating in the negotiations with the plaintiffs, including John Uster. In so doing, the plaintiffs necessarily released John Uster from any restriction on the use of the Confidential Information to which he would otherwise have been subject up to that time. Accordingly, John Uster stood in the same position as the Investor Defendants.[15]

The motions judge noted that Steven Uster's involvement with the Kaptor group of companies was limited to his position as a director and officer of a sister company of Insignia, Elkap Financial, which was also a subsidiary of the plaintiff Kaptor Financial Inc. This was not enough to establish a per se fiduciary relationship to any of the plaintiffs. The pleadings also failed to establish a basis for an ad hoc fiduciary relationship. Steven Uster's position was identical to that of the Investor Defendants. The fact that he may have received the Confidential Information earlier than the Investor Defendants as a result of his presence in the offices of Kaptor Financial Inc. was not sufficient to distinguish his position from that of the Investor Defendants. In particular, there was no pleading that he undertook not to support a receivership application in furtherance of his interests as a creditor as a result of his receipt of the Confidential Information. His position was identical to that of John Uster. Most importantly, delivery of the Confidential Information to the Investor Defendants also released Steven Uster from any restriction on the use of the Confidential Information to which he would otherwise have been subject.[16]
LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resources Ltd. (1989), 61 D.L.R. (4th) 14, [1989] 2 S.C.R. 574.
Genesta Manufacturing Ltd. v. Babey (1984), 48 O.R. (2d) 94, 29 B.L.R. 36 (H.C.J.).
Canadian Aero Service Ltd. v. O'Malley (1973), 40 D.L.R. (3d) 371, [1974] 1 S.C.R. 592.

Genesta Manufacturing Ltd. v. Babey (1984), 48 O.R. (2d) 94, at p. 103, 29 B.L.R. 36 (H.C.J.), citing Canadian Aero Service Ltd. v. O'Malley (1973), 40 D.L.R. (3d) 371, at p. 384, [1974] 1 S.C.R. 592.
Coin-A-Matic (Pacific) Ltd. v. Saibil (1986), 13 C.C.E.L. 59, 12 C.P.R. (3d) 33 (B.C.S.C.).

See Faccenda Chicken Ltd. v. Fowler, [1986] 1 All E.R. 617 (C.A.). The expiry dates in Coin-A-Matic (Pacific) Ltd. v. Saibil (1986), 13 C.C.E.L. 59, 12 C.P.R. (3d) 33 (B.C.S.C.), were held to be equivalent to the information about chicken prices in the Faccenda case, which were also held not to be confidential.
Coin-A-Matic (Pacific) Ltd. v. Saibil (1986), 13 C.C.E.L. 59, at pp. 85–6, 12 C.P.R. (3d) 33 (B.C.S.C.).
Kaptor Financial Inc. v. Alexander, 2014 CarswellOnt 7388, 2014 ONSC 2185.

Kaptor Financial Inc. v. Alexander, 2014 CarswellOnt 7388, 2014 ONSC 2185, at paras. 23–24.
Kaptor Financial Inc. v. Alexander, 2014 CarswellOnt 7388, 2014 ONSC 2185, at paras. 26–29.
Kaptor Financial Inc. v. Alexander, 2014 CarswellOnt 7388, 2014 ONSC 2185, at para. 30.
